reply_context.text: When it comes to the CVL term we specifically went with it to discriminate CLIP-like VLMs from the VLMs that can generate text as the term VLM is overused and means many different things in different papers. It to an extent also follows the naming from arxiv.org/pdf/2405.17247

posts.text:
... I see what you're trying to communicate now. The way you're articulating this is very confusing though. I don't think I'd ever seen the phrase "CVL" prior to this, and had always seen CLIP et. al categorized as SSL. 

I'm groggy from just waking up, but the DINO lit should have relevant language

reply_context.text: CLIP is a SSL method, and I've never seen it described as a VLM. VLM implies that it can generate text. CLIP is just an encoder, it doesn't generate text or images, just embeddings which were learned via a contrastive SSL objective.

posts.text: CLIP is a SSL method, and I've never seen it described as a VLM. VLM implies that it can generate text. CLIP is just an encoder, it doesn't generate text or images, just embeddings which were learned via a contrastive SSL objective.

reply_context.text: Image processing parameters can be recovered from the representations of frozen models by training a linear layer on top. This ability is especially pronounced for contrastive VLMs (e.g., CLIP). Some supervised models perform strongly as well, while SSL models perform the worst.

posts.text:
Quantum mechanics is taught upside down. So much of the material is conveying unintuitive properties of probability/waves/discretization that are not specific to subatomic phenomena. 

Physics pedagogy needs to decouple the subatomic weirdness from the "this is actually how everything works" stuff.

Prompting it for "incremental development" can be dangerous to. It likes to tack on new functionality as "plugins" and generally add complexity to e.g. maintain backwards compatibility during the code change.
